speaker: Stuart Yeager
words: We're going to start by asking you a couple of questions about your parents' occupations and their educational background and your home town. Why don't we start with your parents' occupations?

speaker: James Lowry
words: Both my parents are postal workers‚ and I was born and raised in Chicago‚ Illinois.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me a little bit about their educational background?

speaker: Lowry
words: High school graduates. Both were high school graduates in Chicago.

speaker: Yeager
words: And they were both from Chicago originally?

speaker: Lowry
words: No‚ from the South. My father's from Tennessee and my mother's from Mississippi.

speaker: Yeager
words: They met in Chicago?

speaker: Lowry
words: They met in Chicago.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you have any idea when they came from the South to Chicago?

speaker: Lowry
words: Yes. When they both were in their teens.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me something about your neighborhood in Chicago? Was it segregated? Desegregated?

speaker: Lowry
words: Segregated. Lower middle class‚ I would say.

speaker: Yeager
words: Your high school?

speaker: Lowry
words: Francis Parker.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me a little bit about the connection between Grinnell and Francis Parker? We have a whole lot of people from Francis Parker.

speaker: Lowry
words: Well‚ I think it's just...if you know anything about Francis Parker‚ Francis Parker is a day school where they spend a lot of emphasis on where students are to go. At one time when I was there‚ it was estimated that the principal spent thirty to forty percent of his time trying to place Francis Parker students in the college or university of their choices‚ and it was just very tough. It was a tough school. I think the other thing was that they tried to fine tune the selection to the personalities‚ and that's why I came here-it was decided. It was almost like a computer.

speaker: Yeager
words: They told you that you were Grinnell material?

speaker: Lowry
words: They told me. Yes. They really‚ they gave us a choicethey gave me a choice of about four schools: basically Lawrence‚ Grinnell‚ Kenyon and Oberlin. I visited three of the four-and one twice. And I just decided to go to Grinnell.

speaker: Yeager
words: A few more questions and then we're going to get to Grinnell. Your parents' religious affiliations and their political affiliations?

speaker: Lowry
words: They were Democrats‚ Lutheran.

speaker: Yeager
words: How important was politics in your family?

speaker: Lowry
words: Not very.

speaker: Yeager
words: It was not discussed a lot?

speaker: Lowry
words: No‚ not to a great-great extent.

speaker: Yeager
words: You discussed a little bit how you chose Grinnell? What were some of the reactions your parents had and your friends had to your going to Grinnell?

speaker: Lowry
words: Well‚ in my case‚ my brother had gone to Kenyon‚ so my brother was four years older. And so it wasn't as unizue a selection because of my brother. In fact‚ my father wanted me to go to Kenyon‚ because my brother had a very illustrious career at Kenyon. But it was an all-boys school‚ and I really didn't wnat to go to an all-boys school. And probably didn't want to follow my brother. But they were very used to a liberal arts college‚ so it was not a big shock.

speaker: Yeager
words: Why a small liberal arts college as opposed to a university?

speaker: Lowry
words: I was very interested in athletics.

speaker: Yeager
words: And you thought you'd get better attention in a small school?

speaker: Lowry
words: No‚ I wanted to participate in three sports. I figured could have played one sport in a major university‚ but I couldn't have played all three.

speaker: Yeager
words: Were you recruited by the college?

speaker: Lowry
words: In the typical Grinnell fashion. No‚ I think we kind of showed up at Grinnell's doorstep. Once we showed up-we meaning Jimmy Simmons and myself-we presented ourselves with our credentials and our board scores and athletic prowess‚ then Grinnell got very interested. But it was not a case where Grinnell said‚ “We want you to come here.“

speaker: Yeager
words: So at that time Grinnell wasn't-at the time was making an active effort to recruit black students?

speaker: Lowry
words: No‚ not really. No.

speaker: Yeager
words: Now‚ Allison Davis came a year later?

speaker: Lowry
words: No. We're all roommates. Allison Davis‚ Jimmy Simmons and myself were roommates in Smith Hall.

speaker: Yeager
words: All three came to the doors at the same time.

speaker: Lowry
words: Yes. But they didn't even know Allison was black.

speaker: Yeager
words: What personal and occupational goals did you set for yourself once you arrived there?

speaker: Lowry

speaker: Yeager
words: Any other goals that you set?

speaker: Lowry
words: Not really. It was ...I don't know why‚ when I look back on it‚ but I really didn't have any career goals. I think that's probably common for a lot of blacks around that era. We were here‚ and this was just the first step‚ going to a good school. And I think we thought‚ you know‚ in terms of professional school‚ but in terms of career‚ no. We were just out there.

speaker: Yeager
words: What was your brother doing?

speaker: Lowry
words: My brother‚ this is an example. My brother left Kenyon and went into the Air Force. That was time when R.O.T.C. was almost in most of the schools. speaker: Lowry

speaker: Yeager

speaker: Lowry
words: No‚ I guess about two years later‚ after coaching at Francis Parker for two years‚ he then went into an executive training program at Inland Steel in Chicago.

speaker: Yeager
words: So what were your primary concerns as a student?

speaker: Lowry

speaker: Yeager

speaker: Lowry

speaker: Lowry

speaker: Yeager

words: Yeah‚ we had small problems‚ but they were-I mean‚ it was the time.
